p: Moraxella catarrhalis is a Gram-negative, aerobic, oxidase-positive diplococcus belonging to the Moracellaceae family that was first described in 1896 [ 87]. For most of the past century, M. catarrhalis was regarded as an upper respiratory tract commensal organism. However since the late 1970s, M. catarrhalis has been recognized as an important and common human respiratory tract pathogen [ 88]. Nasopharyngeal colonization is more prevalent among infants compared with adults, with colonization rates varying between 33 and 100% in infants from different parts of the world [ 89– 91]. M. catarrhalis is also a common cause of otitis media in infants and children, causing 15–20% of acute otitis media episodes [ 88].
